bcl:section.bcl:text:
This Act comes into force by regulation of the Lieutenant Governor in
          Council.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prohibition on possession of body armour

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

            of, or provides any aspect of the services provided by, a security guard service, as

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A person must not possess body armour except under the authority of a valid body
            armour permit issued in the person's name.
Subsection (2) does not apply to a person who

bcl:text:
holds a valid security worker licence authorizing the person to perform the
              work of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an armoured car guard,

a security consultant,

a body armour salesperson,

bcl:section.bcl:text:
If the basis on which a person who possesses body armour is exempt under section 2 (3)
          from the requirement to hold a body armour permit changes so that the exemption no longer
          applies, the person, within 14 days after that change, must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
return or sell the body armour to the person's employer, if the exemption was
            based on the person's employment and the employer is exempt from the requirement to hold
            a body armour permit,
destroy the body armour, or

sell the body armour to a person who holds a valid security business licence
            authorizing the sale of body armour.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
An individual may apply to the registrar for a body armour permit or renewal of
            a body armour permit.
An application for a body armour permit or renewal must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be made in the form and manner required by the registrar,

include authorizations for the registrar to carry out the prescribed checks
              regarding the applicant or permit holder, and
be accompanied by the prescribed fee.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
An applicant for a body armour permit or the renewal of a body armour permit
            must meet all conditions and requirements imposed by this Act or the
            regulations.

The registrar may refuse to issue or renew a body armour permit if any of the
            following applies:

bcl:text.#text:
the applicant or permit holder fails in any way to comply with, or does not
              meet the requirements of, section 4 ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the registrar considers that the applicant or permit holder has failed to
              demonstrate a need to possess or continue to possess body armour;

the registrar considers that it is not in the public interest for the
              applicant or permit holder to possess or continue to possess body armour;
the applicant or permit holder has been convicted of a crime.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The registrar must hold a hearing before making a decision under subsection
              (1).

The registrar must give the applicant or permit holder written reasons for a
            decision under subsection (1).

The registrar may issue or renew a body armour permit for a term not exceeding
            the prescribed period.
The registrar may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
impose any terms and conditions on a body armour permit that the registrar
              considers appropriate, and
amend or remove those terms and conditions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The registrar must give the applicant or permit holder written reasons for a
            decision under subsection (2).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Terms and conditions of body armour permit
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following are terms and conditions of every body armour permit:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the permit holder must carry the permit at all times when body armour is in the permit holder's possession;

the permit holder, when having body armour in the permit holder's possession, must
            produce the body armour permit on the request of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an inspector, or
a peace officer;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the permit holder must report to the registrar within 14 days of its
            occurrence,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the theft or loss of the permit,

a change in the permit holder's employment, if possession of body armour under the
              permit is for the purposes of that employment,
a change in the permit holder's residential address, or

a charge being laid or a conviction entered against the holder for a
              crime;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
on or before the last day of the term of the body armour permit, the permit
            holder must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: surrender the permit to the registrar, and

provide evidence satisfactory to the registrar that the body armour has
              been

bcl:clause.bcl:text:
returned or sold to the person's employer if possession of body armour under
                the permit was for the purposes of employment and the employer is exempt from the
                requirement to hold a body armour permit,

sold to a person who holds a valid security business licence authorizing the
                sale of body armour;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the permit holder must

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: comply with this Act and the regulations, and
comply with the terms and conditions of the permit;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the permit holder must not allow another person to use the body armour
            permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Except as authorized under this Act, a person who does not hold a valid security
            business licence or a valid security worker licence, authorizing the sale of body
            armour, must not sell body armour to another person.

A person who holds a valid security business licence or a valid security worker
            licence, authorizing the sale of body armour, must not sell body armour to another
            person unless that other person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: holds a valid body armour permit, or
is exempt from the requirement to hold a body armour permit.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A person who holds a valid security business licence authorizing the sale of
            body armour must not employ another person to sell body armour unless that other person
            holds a valid security worker licence authorizing the person to sell body
            armour.

bcl:text.#text:
The  applies in
            relation to a security business licence authorizing the sale of body armour and, for
            that purpose, the references in sections 15 (1) (d) (ii), 16 (5) (a), 31 (a), 34 (1),
            35 (1) (a) and (5) and 42 (1) (a) and (b) and (3) of that Act to "this Act" are deemed
            to include this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
This section does not apply to a person who sells body armour only on a
            wholesale basis and only to a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
holds a valid security business licence authorizing the sale of body armour,
              or
sells body armour on a wholesale basis.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Body armour permit cancellation or suspension

bcl:text.#text:
The registrar may cancel, or suspend for a period of time, a body armour permit
            for any reason under section 5 (1) .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The registrar must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hold a hearing before making a decision under subsection (1), and
provide the permit holder with written reasons for the decision.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If under subsection (1) the registrar cancels a body armour permit, the permit
            holder, immediately or within the period specified by the registrar in the decision or
            reasons, must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: surrender the permit to the registrar, and

provide evidence satisfactory to the registrar that the body armour has
              been

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
returned or sold to the person's employer, if possession of the body armour
                under the permit was for the purposes of employment and the employer is exempt from
                the requirement to hold a body armour permit,
destroyed, or

sold to a person who holds a valid security business licence authorizing the
                sale of body armour.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If under subsection (1) the registrar suspends a body armour permit for a period of
            time, the permit holder, immediately or within the period specified by the registrar in
            the decision or reasons, must surrender the permit and the body armour to the registrar
            for that period.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Summary action to protect the public

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If the registrar considers it necessary to protect the public, the registrar,
            immediately and without notice, may cancel, or suspend for a period of time, a body
            armour permit.

As soon as practicable after making a decision under subsection
              (1), the registrar must provide the permit holder with written notice of
            and reasons for the decision.

A body armour permit holder who receives a notice under subsection
              (2) must immediately surrender the permit and body armour to the registrar
            or, if the notice is delivered by an inspector or a peace officer, to the inspector or
            peace officer, and may file a written reply with the registrar within 15 days after the
            date of the notice.

bcl:text.#text:
Section 29 (4) to (7) of the  applies to a suspension or cancellation under this section
            and, for that purpose, a reference in that section

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:

                subsection
                (1) of this section, and

to subsection (3) is deemed to be a reference to subsection
                (3) of this section.

bcl:text.#text:
If the permit holder does not file a written reply to a registrar's notice that
            the body armour permit is cancelled or the registrar's decision under section 29 (4) of
            the , as that section applies under
            subsection (4) of this section, results in the body armour permit being cancelled, the
            registrar may destroy the body armour at the expiration of the 15-day period under
            subsection (3) of this section or upon giving written reasons under section 29 (6) of
            the , as applicable.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
An inspector may conduct an inspection for one or both of the following
          purposes:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
determining whether a person is in compliance with this Act, the regulations or
            the terms and condition of the person's body armour permit;

bcl:text.#text: assisting the registrar in making a decision under section 5 , 9  or 10 .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who contravenes section 8 (1) or (2) commits an offence.

When applying for a body armour permit or when requested, ordered or directed by
            the registrar or an inspector to provide information, a person must not provide false or
            misleading information.

A person does not commit an offence under subsection (3) if, at the time
            the information was supplied, the person did not know that the information was false or
            misleading and, with the exercise of reasonable diligence, could not have known that the
            information was false or misleading.

A person must not obstruct, impede or refuse to admit an inspector or a peace
            officer who is exercising powers or performing duties under this Act or a warrant issued
            under, or for the purposes of enforcing, this Act.

A person must not use a body armour permit that has been issued to another
            person.

If a business entity commits an offence under subsection (2), an employee,
            officer, director, partner or agent of the business entity who authorizes, permits or
            acquiesces in the commission of the offence also commits an offence.

Subsection (7) applies whether or not the business entity is prosecuted
            for the offence.

A charge for an offence under this section may not be laid more than one year
            after the commission of the offence.

bcl:text.#text:
Section
              5 of the  does not apply for the
            purposes of this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
An individual who commits an offence under section 13 is liable on
            conviction to a fine of not more than $10 000 or imprisonment for not longer than 6
            months, or both.

A business entity that commits an offence under section 13 (2) is liable on
            conviction to a fine of not more than $100 000.

If the registrar imposes an administrative penalty on a person, a prosecution
            for an offence under this Act for the same contravention may not be brought against the
            person.

A person who has been charged with an offence under this Act may not be subject
            to an administrative penalty in respect of the circumstances that gave rise to the
            charge.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
The registrar must establish and maintain a registry in which the registrar must
          keep a record of

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:

            permit,

every security business licence and security worker licence, authorizing the
            sale of body armour, issued by the registrar and the current status of the licence,
            and

every application for a body armour permit, security business licence or
            security worker licence that is refused by the registrar and the reasons for the
            refusal.

If an inspector or a peace officer has reasonable grounds for believing that a

            inspector or peace officer, the person

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Without limiting subsection (1), the Lieutenant Governor in Council may
            make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: respecting forms of applications and body armour permits;

bcl:text.#text:
prescribing garments and items for the purposes of paragraph (b) of the
              definition of "body armour" in section 1 ;

prescribing checks regarding applicants for the purposes of section 4 (2)
                (b) ;

prescribing fees for the purpose of section 4 (2) (c)  which may be different
              depending on the duration of the body armour permit;
prescribing a maximum period for the purposes of section 6 (1) ;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
prescribing the information that an applicant for a body armour permit is
              required to provide;

authorizing the registrar to exempt a person for a prescribed period from the
              requirement to hold a body armour permit despite any provision of the Act if the
              registrar is satisfied that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
the person does not reside in British Columbia and the nature of the
                person's proposed activities in British Columbia make it desirable that the person
                be authorized to possess body armour, or

because of an imminent risk to the person's safety, it is desirable that the
                person be authorized to possess body armour;

bcl:text.#text: prescribing provisions for the purposes of section 12 (4) ;

establishing an offence for the contravention of a regulation and prescribing
              a penalty for that offence up to the maximum penalties set out in section 14
                (1) .
